Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

ALLEGATION:
On 6/02/21, staff were attempting to verbally de-escalate a youth. Another staff
member came to the side of the youth which escalated youth who began hitting staff
member. Staff member reached out with open hand and arm extended towards
youth but did not appear to make contact. Other staff stepped in to create a barrier.
INVESTIGATION:
On 6/2/2021 at 9:00AM I made an unannounced visit to the facility during which I
made a face-to-face observation of Youth A, a non-verbal child, who did not appear
to have any visible injuries. I also made face-to-face contact with Staff 1.
INTERVIEWS
Clinician - On 6/4/2021 I interviewed Clinician by phone. He reported that he and
Shift Supervisor were on the unit with Youth A who was escalated, utilizing verbal
de-escalation techniques and a tablet to communicate. All of the other youth were
either in their bedrooms or in the cafeteria and there were no other staff on the unit
at the time until Staff 1 came out of the cafeteria and stood in the hallway between
the cafeteria and the milieu area where Clinician and Shift Supervisor were working
with Youth A. Youth A went over to Staff 1 and started hitting and slapping her.
Clinician saw Staff 1 raise her right arm with an open hand and swing toward Youth
A’s face. Clinician did not see or hear Staff 1’s hand make contact with Youth A.
Clinician stated that this did not appear to be a block or a defensive move as Staff 1
leaned into the swing. Clinician reported that he and Shift Supervisor placed
themselves between Staff 1 and Youth A and continued to attempt verbal de-
escalation techniques. Clinician spoke with Shift Supervisor to confirm that he saw
the swing as well at which time they reported the incident to administration. Clinician
reported that he was shocked that Staff 1 had done this as he has never seen her
act this way in the past and has had no concerns with her interactions with youth.
Shift Supervisor – On 6/4/2021 I interviewed Shift Supervisor by phone. Shift
Supervisor reported that he and Clinician attempted to verbally de-escalate Youth A
who was in the hallway area of the unit when Staff 1 entered the area. Youth A
started hitting Staff 1 and Staff 1 responded by swinging with an open hand in a
slapping motion toward Youth A. Youth A was backing up at the time, so Staff 1’s
3

hand went over Youth A’s head. He denied seeing Staff 1 make any physical contact
with Youth A. Shift Supervisor stated that he and Clinician looked at one another
when it happened, acknowledging that they had both seen the same thing. After
Youth A was de-escalated, Shift Supervisor and Clinician talked about what they had
seen and made a report to administration. Shift Supervisor stated that he does not
typically work with Staff 1, but he has never seen her do anything like this previously.
Staff 1 – On 6/4/2021 I interviewed Staff 1 by phone. When provided with the details
of the allegation, Staff 1 stated that the only time she could recall moving her arm
while Youth A was hitting her was as Youth A was seated and Staff 1 walked past.
Staff 1 had her arm up to block Youth A from hitting her, then quickly swung her arm
down, to block a hit. She stated that she was shocked at how fast she moved her
own arm, but she was still not able to block the hit to her hip in time. Staff 1 stated
that she then continued walking past Youth A. She reported that she did not recall a
time that they were standing in the hallway/doorway area while Youth A was hitting
Staff 1 and denied ever striking toward Youth A.
DOCUMENTS
Incident Report - On 6/3/2021 I received and reviewed a copy an Incident Report
(IR) completed by Clinician on 6/3/2021 in which he documented the same details
he reported during his interview.
Staff Training & Disciplinary History - On 6/6/2021 I received and reviewed a
copy of Staff 1’s training records indicating that she is current on her training. On
6/15/2021 I received and reviewed Staff 1’s disciplinary history which included
documentation of verbal coaching on 3/15/2021 for use of inappropriate language in
the workplace and on 4/5/2021 for failure to follow call-in procedure.
Safety Plan – On 6/2/2021 I spoke with Chief Administrator who indicated that the
facility immediately sent Staff 1 home after the incident and she will be placed on
leave pending the investigation results, ensuring that she would not have any
contact with Youth A. On 6/3/2021 I received and reviewed a copy of the safety plan
written by the youth’s assigned foster care worker and which was signed by the
Chief Administrator of the facility. The safety plan indicated that the Staff 1 and
Youth A would have no contact with one another during the course of this
investigation and that facility staff will continue to follow the previously established
Behavioral Plan with Youth A.
Policy – On 6/14/2021 I received and reviewed a copy of the facility’s Behavior
Management policy which states that staff will utilize positive interventions. I also
reviewed the discipline policy which indicates that any type of corporal punishment is
prohibited, and that staff are to use Satori Alternatives to Managing Aggression
(SAMA.) The SAMA Manual outlines that staff members should “slide step” away
from a strike and hold hands together, raising them to forehead height with elbows
rib cage width apart, and move both arms as a unit slightly to either side to block a
strike.
4

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4157 Behavior management.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written
policies and procedures that describe the
institution’s behavior management system. The
policies and procedures shall be reviewed annually
and updated as needed. These shall be available to
all residents, their families, and referring agencies.
ANALYSIS: Staff 1 did not follow the facility’s policies regarding behavior
management when Clinician and Shift Supervisor observed her
striking her hand toward Youth A.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
